statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \sin 4 x \cdot \sin 8 x \,

step.context: \text{Are the following calculations and analysis correct?}
step.tex:
\text{Using trignometric identity,}\\
\begin{align}
\sin A \sin B &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos (A-B) - \cos (A+B)] \\ \implies \sin 4 x \cdot \sin 8 x &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos 4 x - \cos 12 x] \\ \end{align}\\
\therefore \int \sin 4 x \cdot \sin 8 x \, dx = \int \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos 4 x - \cos 12 x] dx
step.reason: \text{Applied the trignometeric identity, }\\ \sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos (A-B) - \cos (A+B)] \\ \text{Check your calculations, if you got something}\\ \text{else.}

step.context: \text{Is the following evaluation of the integral}\\ \int \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos 4 x - \cos 12 x] dx \quad \text{correct}?
step.tex:
\int \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos 4 x - \cos 12 x] dx \\ = \dfrac{1}{2}\int \cos (4 x) dx - \dfrac{1}{2}\int \cos (12 x) dx \\
= \dfrac {1} {2}\left[ \dfrac{1}{4}{\sin4 x} - \dfrac{1}{12}{\sin 12 x}\right]+ C
step.reason: \int \cos (a x)dx = \dfrac{\sin (a x)}{a}+ C \\ \text{where C is the constant of integration.}
